column1: Metairie ( MET-ər-ee) is a census-designated place (CDP) in Jefferson Parish
column2: Louisiana
column4: and is part of the New Orleans metropolitan area. With a population at the 2010 census of 138
column6: Metairie is the largest community in Jefferson Parish and the fifth-largest CDP in the United States. It is an unincorporated area that would be Louisiana's fourth-largest city if it were incorporated.

column1: Métairie (French: [me.tɛ.ʁi]) is the French term for a small tenant farm which paid the landlord with a share of the produce
column2: a practice also known as sharecropping (in French
column4: many of the original French farmers were tenants; after the Civil War
column5: the majority of the community's inhabitants were sharecroppers until urbanization started in the 1910s.

column2: French settlers became the first Europeans to settle Metairie in the area known then as Tchoupitoulas and now as Metairie Ridge
column3: a natural levee formed by an ancient branch of the Mississippi River
column5: which flowed through modern-day River Ridge
column8: and New Orleans East. It emptied into Mississippi Sound. The Acolapissa Native Americans used this ridge as a road; it is the oldest road in the New Orleans area. Paved in the 1920s
column9: it is called Metairie Road. An electric streetcar was installed running along Metairie Road in the late 1910s
column10: opening the area to greater development. Upscale housing tracts were constructed off the road in the 1920s; this area is now known as "Old Metairie". It is today the most prestigious area of Metairie. The areas to the north and northwest of Metairie Road were not developed until after World War II. The land between Metairie Ridge and Lake Pontchartrain
column11: which was cypress swamps and marshlands
column12: was drained with the Wood Pump. With development of this new land for residences
column13: Metairie's population grew in the 1940s as a result of cheaper land
column15: and larger lots as compared to Orleans Parish.

column2: Metairie made history when one of its districts elected white supremacist David Duke to the Louisiana state legislature for a single term. On August 29
column4: Hurricane Katrina caused a new migration from Orleans Parish
column5: because housing was needed to replace what had been destroyed in the flooding of the city. It has been a racially neutral migration
column6: with equal numbers of black and white residents moving to Jefferson Parish. The 2010 Census showed that Metairie has increasingly become more diverse.

column1: Veterans Boulevard was laid out alongside a drainage canal
column2: and became a commercial center of the region. The central business district of Metairie is located on Causeway Boulevard near Lake Pontchartrain. Metairie also has one of the handful of major malls located in the New Orleans metro area. Lakeside Shopping Center is the highest-grossing mall in the New Orleans metropolitan area. In the 1970s and early 1980s
column3: an area of bars and nightclubs opened in a section of Metairie known as "Fat City"
column4: which is now the most racially diverse area in the New Orleans metropolitan area and is home to a vibrant restaurant scene. Several New Orleans radio and television stations have transmitter facilities in Metairie and Jefferson Parish; two of them
column6: now have studios and main offices in Metairie.  Metairie has a large Mardi Gras season that touts itself as more family-friendly than the New Orleans Mardi Gras.

column1: Metairie is located in eastern Jefferson Parish and is bordered by New Orleans to the east
column2: Kenner to the west
column4: and the Illinois Central Railroad tracks to the south. South of the railroad are River Ridge
column7: and Jefferson. The 17th Street Canal forms the border between Metairie and New Orleans to the east. It is a principal community in Greater New Orleans. According to the U.S. Census Bureau
column8: the Metairie CDP has a total area of 23.2 square miles (60.2 km2)
column9: of which 23.2 square miles (60.1 km2) is land and 0.04 square miles (0.1 km2)

column1: The climate of Metairie has been classified as humid subtropical. Like the city of New Orleans
column2: it has short
column4: humid summers. The average precipitation is 62.5 in (1
column5: 590 mm) annually; the summer months are the wettest
column6: while October is the driest month. Precipitation in winter usually accompanies the passing of a cold front. On average
column7: there are 77 days of 90 °F (32 °C) or greater highs
column8: 8.1 days per winter where the high does not exceed 50 °F (10 °C)
column9: and 8.0 nights with freezing lows annually. It is rare for the temperature to reach 20 or 100 °F (−6.7 or 37.8 °C)
column10: with the last occurrence of each being February 5

column2: 54.1% of residents identify with some religion. Due to Spanish and French colonial influence
column3: Metairie and the surrounding area have an overwhelmingly Catholic populace. 34.6% identify with the Catholic Church
column4: served by the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New Orleans. 5.9% are Baptist
column10: and 0.5% from another Christian group including the Metropolitan Community Church among others.0.7% are Muslims and 0.4% identify with an Eastern religion such as Hinduism
column12: or Sikhism. 0.6% of the community claim affiliation with Judaism. Metairie is home to Congregation Gates of Prayer

column15: the oldest Orthodox congregation in the New Orleans metro area. Beth Israel constructed its new building in Metairie in 2012

column1: Jefferson Parish Library operates public libraries. The East Bank Regional Library
column2: which houses the library system's headquarters
column3: is in Metairie. Other public libraries in Metairie include the Lakeshore Library

column1: Metairie was home to the New Orleans Baby Cakes Triple-A Minor League Baseball team of the Pacific Coast League from 1993 to 2019. The minor league club played its home games at Privateer Park
column2: home to the University of New Orleans' NCAA baseball team
column4: and at Shrine on Airline from 1997 to 2019.

column1: The training facilities of NFL franchise New Orleans Saints and the NBA franchise New Orleans Pelicans are located in Metairie. As such
column2: many players reside in the area.Boxing cards have been held in the Copeland Tower Suites (formerly Landmark Hotel).Beginning in 2020
column3: the NOLA Gold of Major League Rugby will play their homes games in Metairie at the Shrine on Airline.

The most common method of transportation within Metairie is the automobile. Mass transit is provided by "JeT" (Jefferson Transit)
column2: but it does not run on Sundays
column5: unlike many lines of New Orleans' RTA. JeT's coverage is also very limited in terms of usability.

column1: Major east–west roads (starting from north to south) include West Esplanade Avenue
column2: Veterans Memorial Boulevard
column6: Airline Drive (which is part of U.S. Route 61) and Jefferson Highway (which is part of U.S. Route 90). The Earhart Expressway
column7: running east–west immediately south of Airline Drive
column8: is the only other freeway entering New Orleans from the west
column9: but it ends as an expressway soon after crossing into Orleans Parish  and well before the New Orleans CBD (in Central City.)

column1: For many of the major east–west roadways
column2: the eastbound and westbound lanes are separated by large
column3: open-topped drainage canals. These canals are one of the most distinct characteristics of the Metairie landscape.  Similar canals once bisected many streets in neighboring New Orleans
column4: but most were covered over in the mid-20th century.

column2: continuous north–south roads (starting from west to east) include Power Boulevard/David Drive/Hickory Avenue
